Description: Body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery closed vessel, possibly a hydria; inside reserved and smooth; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of part of quadriga team (forelegs of at least three horses and hind leg of one; near pole horse’s legs in added white), to right; at far side of horses, lower part of male (wearing winged boots edged and dotted with white, spotted animal skin with pointed ends hanging between his legs) and woman in long peplos (chequer-board pattern with crosses; part of advanced foot in white visible) moving together, to right; facing them, lower part of male with naked legs and winged boots (wing edged with white, white dots on top of foot, red on boot); below, black line and black zone.
Curator's comments: The drawing of winged boots is not close to the Affecter and the arrangement of the overlapping figures would be unique for the painter - Mommsen, H., Der Affecter. Mainz 1975, 115.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B600.46)
Beazley & Payne 1929 / Attic Black Figured Fragments from Naukratis (p. 264, no. 42)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 295-6, no. B281)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 234, no. 2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0110) (Phase 1)
